| casualties_label = | notes = }} {{History of Bahrain}} The '''2011 Bahraini uprising''', sometimes called the '''February 14 Revolution''' ({{lang-ar|Ø«ÙØ±Ø© 14 ÙØ¨Ø±Ø§ÙØ± }}) is a series of demonstrations, amounting to a sustained campaign of [[civil resistance]], in the [[Persian Gulf]] country of [[Bahrain]]. As part of the [[revolutionary wave]] of protests in the [[Arab Spring|Middle East and North Africa]] following the self-immolation of [[Mohammed Bouazizi]] in Tunisia, the Bahraini protests were initially aimed at achieving greater [[political freedom]] and equality for the majority [[Shia]] population,[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/wikileaks-files/bahrain-wikileaks-cables/8334600/BAHRAINS-SHIA-POLITICAL-LEADERS-VISIT-IRAQ.html "Bahrain Shi Leaders Visit Iraq"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. Retrieved 20 January 2011. and expanded to a call to end the [[King of Bahrain|monarchy]] of [[King Hamad]] following a deadly night raid on 17 February against protesters at the [[Pearl Roundabout]] in [[Manama]].{{cite news | author=[[Staff writer]] | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12490286 | title = Bahrain Protests: Police Break Up Pearl Square Crowd |publisher=BBC News | date=17 February 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011}} Protesters in Manama camped out for days at the Pearl Roundabout, which functioned as the centre point of protests there. After a month, the government requested [[Peninsula Shield Force#2011|troops]] and police from the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]], which arrived on 14 March, and a day later, the king of Bahrain declared [[martial law]] and a three-month [[state of emergency]].{{cite news | title = Bahrain King Declares State of Emergency after Protests | author=[[Staff writer]] | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12745608 |publisher=BBC News | date=15 March 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011}}{{cite news | author=Cloud, David S.; Banerjee, Neela | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-bahrain-flashpoint-20110316,0,1785627.story | title = Bahrain Protests: In Bahrain, Forces Move Against Protesters in Capital â Military Units and Police Push into Pearl Square Early Wednesday; Shooting Is Heard, But There Is No Word on Casualties â A Day Earlier, Bahrain's King Imposed a Three-Month State of Emergency and Ordered the Military To Battle the Unrest |work=Los Angeles Times | date=16 March 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011}} The police response has been described as a "brutal" crackdown on peaceful and unarmed protestors, including doctors and bloggers.Law, Bill (6 April 2011). The [[Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry]] was established on 29 June 2011 by King [[Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa]] to assess the incidents that occurred in the Kingdom during the period of unrest in February and March 2011 and the consequences of these events.''Bahrain News Agency'', [http://bna.bh/portal/en/news/462963 "HM King Hamad Sets up Royal Independent Investigation Commission"], ''Bahrain News Agency'', 29 June 2011 The Commission reported its findings on 23 November 2011.http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/11/20111123125645404851.html ==Background== {{see|History of Bahrain|Human rights in Bahrain|Torture in Bahrain}} Bahrain's [[Shia]] majority has often complained of receiving poor treatment in employment, housing, and infrastructure, while [[Sunni]]s have preferential status. The [[government of Bahrain|Bahraini government]] has reportedly imported Sunnis from [[Pakistan]] and [[Syria]] in an attempt to increase the Sunni percentage. {{registration required|date=April 2011}} {{cite news | url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/62ff2670-3ac7-11e0-9c1a-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1EFxkS8Zd | title = Bahrain Gets Tough |work=Financial Times | date=17 February 2011 }} Shiite Muslims are blocked from serving in important political and military posts.{{dead link|date=April 2011}} {{cite news | url = http://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5hNhyOE-lRoOulNqChIha9uXbO0wQ?docId=5994860 | title = Issues Behind Protests in Bahrain | publisher=Associated Press (via [[Google News]]) | date=18 February 2011 }} Bahrain does have the [[National Assembly of Bahrain]], a popularly elected parliament, but it is not powerful. Occasional protests have flared up since the reign of [[Isa bin Salman Al Khalifa]], and, as of 18 February 2011, twenty-five Shiite activists were on trial for subverting state power. Bahrain hosts the United States [[Naval Support Activity Bahrain]], the home of the [[United States Fifth Fleet|US Fifth Fleet]], and is thus crucial to [[United States Department of Defense|US Department of Defense]] attempts to counter [[Military of Iran|Iranian military]] power in the region. The [[government of Saudi Arabia|Saudi Arabian government]] and other [[Gulf region]] governments strongly support the [[King of Bahrain]].{{cite news | url= http://www.theworldreporter.com/2011/03/saudi-arabian-troops-enter-bahrain.html | title= Saudi Arabian Troops Enter Bahrain, Bahrain Opposition Calls It War | author=Shrivastava, Sanskar | work=[[The World Reporter]] | date=15 March 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011 }} The influence of [[Iran]], a majority-Shiite nation, is disputed. Some, including those in regional intelligence circles, believe it to exert significant influence on the protestors.Richard Miniter [http://www.forbes.com/sites/richardminiter/2011/08/18/the-exciting-notion-of-arab-spring-is-a-jedi-mind-trick/ "The Arab Spring Is A Jedi Mind Trick"], ''Forbes'', 18 August 2011 Iran has historically claimed Bahrain as a province and has provided ideological and material support for some important Shia movements, including the [[Haq Movement]] and [[al-Wefaq]].Adrian Blomfield [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/bahrain/7983095/Bahrain-hints-at-Iranian-involvement-in-plot-to-overthrow-government.html "Bahrain hints at Iranian involvement in plot to overthrow government"], ''The Telegraph'', 6 September 2011JAFRIANEWS [http://jafrianews.com/2011/03/04/if-saudi-arabia-intervene-in-bahrain-affairs-opposition-will-ask-help-from-iran "If Saudi Arabia Intervene in Bahrain Affairs, Opposition will Ask Help from Iran"], ''Jafria News'', 4 March 2011 Bahrain has been described as a geopolitical battlefield where the interests of Saudi Arabia and Iran converge.George Friedman [http://www.stratfor.com/weekly/20110307-bahrain-and-battle-between-iran-and-saudi-arabia "Bahrain and the Battle Between Iran and Saudi Arabia"], ''STRATFOR'', 8 March 2011 Bahrain was ranked 13th{{when|date=April 2011}} in the [[Economist Intelligence Unit]] [[Shoe-Thrower's index]],{{cite news | url = http://www.economist.com/blogs/dailychart/2011/02/daily_chart_arab_unrest_index | author=[[Staff writer]] | title = Arab Unrest Index â The Shoe-Thrower's Index |work=The Economist | date=9 February 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011 }} which is an attempt to gauge "unrest" in [[Arab world]] countries. Bahrain is ranked 10 in the [[Heritage Foundation]]âs 2011 [[Index of Economic Freedom]] and is ranked 28 in the [[World Bank]]âs 2011 Ease of Doing Business Index.2011 Index of Economic Freedom [http://www.heritage.org/index/Ranking "Ranking the Countries"], ''2011 Index of Economic Freedom '', 2011 The World Bank [http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/IC.BUS.EASE.XQ "Ease of doing business index (1=most business-friendly regulations) Ease of doing business index (1=most business-friendly regulations) "], ''The World Bank'', 2010 An [[Bahraini parliamentary election, 2010|election]] to the parliament in 2010 was followed by controversy as well. However, the Shia-majority [[Al Wefaq|Al Wefaq National Islamic Society]] won a plurality.{{cite web | author=Seznec, Jean-Francois â essay | date=18 February 2011 | url = http://www.npr.org/2011/02/18/133861647/foreign-policy-bahrain-spells-trouble-for-us-policy | title = Foreign Policy: Bahrain Spells Trouble For US Policy | publisher=[[NPR]] | accessdate=15 April 2011}} ==Overview== [[File:Hamad-Bin-Isa-Al-Khalifa.jpg|thumb|left|King Hamad has instigated the [[Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry]] to look into the events of the uprising, following calls for an end to his rule.]] The date 14 February 2011 was chosen because it was the tenth anniversary of a referendum in favour of the [[National Action Charter of Bahrain]]. Bahraini youths described their plans as an appeal for Bahrainis "to take to the streets on Monday 14 February in a peaceful and orderly manner" in order to rewrite the [[Constitution of Bahrain|constitution]] and to establish a body with a "full popular mandate to investigate and hold to account [[human rights in Bahrain|economic, political and social violations]], including stolen public wealth, political naturalisation, arrests, [[torture in Bahrain|torture]] and other oppressive security measures, ''[and]'' institutional and economic corruption."{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|title= Calls for Weekend Protests in Syria â Social Media Used in Bid To Mobilise Syrians for Rallies Demanding Freedom, Human Rights and the End to Emergency Law|date=4 February 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122171649677912.html |accessdate=31 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wLygnerq |archivedate=8 February 2011 |deadurl=no }} They referred to the uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt as motivations for their appeal.[[Al Wefaq|Al Wefaq National Islamic Society]], which won a plurality in the recent parliamentary election, participated in the planning for demonstrations on 14 February. {{cite news | author=[[Staff writer]] | title = IFR: Bahrain Set To Test Egyptian Contagion | date=11 February 2011 | publisher=[[IFR]] (via [[Reuters]]) | url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/emerging-markets-bahrain-idUSLDE71924E20110210?sp=true | accessdate=31 March 2011 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wQa6Joby | archivedate=11 February 2011 |deadurl=no }} The [[Bahrain Centre for Human Rights]] described authorities' preparations for the 14 February planned demonstrations as "a state of confusion, apprehension and anticipation". On 11 February, King [[Hamad ibn Isa Al Khalifa]] ordered that {{currency|1000|BHD|first=true}} (approximately {{currency|2667|USD}}) be given to "each family" to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the [[National Action Charter of Bahrain|National Action Charter]] referendum.{{cite news | author=[[Staff writer]] | title = Bahrain's King Gifts $3,000 to Every Family | date=11 February 2011 | publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] (via [[France 24]]) | url = http://www.france24.com/en/20110211-bahrains-king-gifts-3000-every-family |accessdate=31 March 2011 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wQZVfMVZ | archivedate=11 February 2011 |deadurl=no }} [[Agence France-Presse]] linked the {{currency|1000|BHD}} payments to the 14 February demonstration plans. On 12 February, the [[Bahrain Centre for Human Rights]] sent an open letter to the king, seeking to avoid a worst-case scenario by "releasing more than 450 detainees including [[Human rights in Bahrain|''[Bahraini]'' human rights]] defenders, religious figures and more than 110 children, dissolv''[ing]'' the [[Politics of Bahrain#National Security|security apparatus]] and ''[prosecuting]'' its official''[s]'' responsible ''[for]'' violations and to start serious dialogue with civil society and opposition groups on disputed issues."{{cite web | author=[[Press release]] | title = An Open Letter to the King of Bahrain To Avoid the Worst Case Scenario | publisher=[[Bahrain Centre for Human Rights]] | date=12 February 2011 | url = http://bahrainrights.org/en/node/3726 | accessdate=31 March 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wTZDwKtv | archivedate=13 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}{{cite news | author=Carey, Glen | title = Bahrain Human-Rights Organization Urges King to Free Detainees | date=13 February 2011 | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-13/bahrain-human-rights-organization-urges-king-to-free-detainees.html | accessdate=31 March 2011 | archiveurl= http://www.webcitation.org/5wTZEm0zK | archivedate=13 February 2011 |deadurl=no }} [[Bahrain Centre for Human Rights|BCHR]] President [[Nabeel Rajab]] stated: "The dissolving of the security apparatus and the prosecution of its officials will not only distance the King from the crimes committed by this apparatus especially since 2005, such as systemic torture and the use of excessive force against peaceful protests, but will avoid the fatal mistake committed by similar apparatuses in [[2010â2011 Tunisian revolution|Tunisia]] and [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egypt ''[revolutions]'']] which led to the loss of lives and hundreds of casualties and eventually resulted in the fall of the regimes who created these 'double edged swords'". Following the raid against the [[Pearl Roundabout]] on 17 February, some protesters started calling for an end to the monarchy.{{cite news | author=[[Staff writer]] | title = Bahrain Mourners Call for End to Monarchy â Mood of Defiance Against Entire Ruling System After Brutal Attack on Pearl Square Protest Camp That Left at Least Five Dead | date=18 February 2011 |publisher=Associated Press (via ''[[The Guardian]]'') | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/18/bahrain-mourners-call-downnfall-monarchy | accessdate=31 March 2011 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5waOzlomm | archivedate=18 February 2011 |deadurl=no | location=London}} Following the clearance of the [[Pearl Roundabout]], the government made an unconditional offer of political dialogue and security forces were withdrawn from the streets.Peter Pearson, [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/bahrain/8681885/Bahrain-and-the-Arab-Spring-time-for-some-realism.html "Bahrain and the Arab Spring: time for some realism"], ''Telegraph'', 4 August 2011 Talks lead by the [[Salman bin Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa|Crown Prince]] were ruined by opposition radicals, who erected road blocks manned by armed vigilantes. According to the [[BBC News]] on 14 March, most of the opposition protesters had said they did not want to overthrow the monarchy but want the ruling family to give up most of its powers to the elected parliament. Some, however, had said they wanted a republic. Though the King has offered dialogue with the protesters, some of them had refused saying they wanted the government to step down.[[Staff writer]] (14 March 2011). [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12729786 "Gulf States Send Forces to Bahrain Following Protests"]. BBC News. Retrieved 31 March 2011. The Shia citizens also demand an end to the mass [[naturalisation]] of Sunni foreigners, primarily from Pakistan, which is seen as an attempt to shift the demographics in the population. The protestors claim that around half the security forces in the army and police force consist of immigrants from Pakistan, Jordan and Yemen.Imtiaz, Saba (17 March 2011). [http://tribune.com.pk/story/133526/pakistani-workers-seek-cover-amid-bahrain-turmoil/ "Pakistani Workers Seek Cover Amid Bahrain Turmoil"]. ''[[The Express Tribune]]''. Retrieved 19 April 2011.Fernandez, Yusuf (19 March 2011). [http://www.presstv.ir/detail/170751.html "Saudis Want To Hijack Bahraini Freedom"]. [[Press TV]]. 19 March 2011. Retrieved 19 April 2011. Journalists who attempted to report human rights abuses were arrested or claimed to have received anonymous death threats. ==Timeline== {{main|Timeline of the 2011 Bahraini uprising}} [[File:Protesters_gathering_in_Pearl_roundabout.jpg|thumb|Protesters gather at the [[Pearl Roundabout]] for the first time on 15 February.]] [[File:Hundreds of thousands of Bahrainis taking part in march of loyalty to martyrs.jpg|thumb|right|Hundreds of thousands of Bahrainis taking part in the "March of Loyalty to Martyrs", honoring political dissidents killed by security forces, on 22 February.]] [[File:Pearl Monument Leveled.jpg|thumb|250px|On the morning of 18 March 2011, the government [[Pearl Roundabout#Demolition|tore down the Pearl Monument]], the rallying point for protests against it.]] [[File:Thousands of demonstrators gather for "Sticking to our national demands" rally in Musalla, Bahrain on July, 22.jpg|thumb|Thousands of demonstrators gather for "Sticking to our national demands" rally in Musalla, Bahrain on July, 22]] Protests began on 14 February 2011, but met immediate resistance from security forces in [[Manama]] and Shia villages. He called for "dialogue" and a direction that the King's son, Crown Prince [[Salman bin Hamad Al Khalifa]], work on a resolution to the conflict.{{cite news | author=Carey, Glen; Alexander, Caroline | url = http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-17/bahrain-security-forces-kill-two-people-overnight-human-rights-groups-say.html | title = Bahrain's King Seeks Talks With Foes Amid Clashes in Region | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date=18 February 2011 | accessdate=21 April 2011}} On 13 March, in a televised statement, Salman bin Hamad Al Khalifa renewed his call for national dialogue, promising talks would address key demands such as bolstering the power of parliament and that any deal could be put to a referendum. He said talks would also cover electoral and governmental reforms, as well as looking into claims of corruption and sectarianism. King Hamad took a series of steps aimed at initiating a period of reconciliation following the unrest in February and March 2011. He established the [[Bahrain national dialogue]] on 1 July 2011 as a forum for the discussion and promotion of reform. The National Dialogue aims to establish âcommon principles for the relaunch of the political reform process," according to Chairman [[Khalifa Al Dhahrani]].BBC News [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13999741 "Bahrain: Sunni leaders begin talks with Shia groups"], ''BBC News â Middle East'', 2 July 2011 The King also established the [[Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry]] (BICI), chaired by noted human rights lawyer [[M. The [[Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry|BICI]] will publicise its report by the end of October 2011. What Next? | publisher=[[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]] | date=20 February 2011 | accessdate=22 April 2011}} and in protest against the deaths during demonstrations, all eighteen party MPs submitted their official resignations from parliament.MOHAMMED AL A'ALI [http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?storyid=305080 "Â Two civic councils face dissolution"], ''Gulf Daily News'', 1 May 2011 Four members of the [[Consultative Council of Bahrain|Shura council]], the upper house of parliament, [[Mohamed Hadi al-Halawji]], [[Mohamed Baqir Hasan Radi]], [[Nasser al-Mubarak]] and [[Nada Hafad]] resigned in protests against the crackdown. Hafad quit first accusing the government and [[state media]] of attempting to foment divisions within Bahraini society. A [[Bahraini parliamentary by-election, 2011|parliamentary by-election]] was held on 24 September 2011Trade Arabia [http://www.tradearabia.com/news/law_202806.html "Bahrain gears up for by-election"], ''Trade Arabia'', 1 Aug 2011 to replace the 18 members of the largest political party in parliament, [[al Wefaq]], who had resigned in protest at governmental actions.{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title= Bahrain holds vote to fill seats vacated during unrest| date=2011-09-24 | publisher=[[Al-Ahram]]/[[Thomson Reuters]] | url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/2/8/22324/World/Region/Bahrain-holds-vote-to-fill-seats-vacated-during-un.aspx |accessdate=2011-09-24 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/61wiRwqtU |archivedate=2011-09-24 |deadurl=no }} Security forces made several arrests on 23 September and on 24 September closed [[Pearl Roundabout]] and attacked protestors in the village of Sanabis, who intended to march to Pearl Roundabout.{{cite news | first=Ethan | last=Bronner | pages= | language =| title=Bahrain Vote Erupts in Violence | date=2011-09-24 | publisher= | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/25/world/middleeast/bahrain-protesters-and-police-clash-during-election.html |accessdate=2011-09-24 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/61wiSVRmj |archivedate=2011-09-24 |deadurl=no | work=The New York Times}} ==International reactions== {{main|International reactions to the 2011 Bahraini uprising}} The uprising has had consequences for Bahrain from the international community as well as foreign investors, including [[Formula One]], which canceled the [[2011 Bahrain Grand Prix]] due to instability and outcry over the actions of the Bahraini government.[[Staff writer]] (21 February 2011). [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/9402871.stm "Bahrain Grand Prix Called Off After Protests"]. BBC News. Retrieved 19 April 2011. Western governments and organisations have generally expressed more magnanimity toward the Bahraini government, seen as a key ally of the [[European Union]] and the United States and a bulwark against nearby [[Iran]], than they have toward other governments accused of violating the human rights of protesters during the [[Arab Spring]].Phillips, Leigh (23 March 2011). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/23/bahrain-protest-crackdown-eu-envoy "Bahrain Protest Crackdown Defended by European Union Envoy â EU Foreign Policy Adviser Robert Cooper Downplays Violence Against Pro-Democracy Protesters Saying 'Accidents Happen'"]. Retrieved 21 April 2011.{{cite news|first=Hugh|last=Tomlinson|agency=The Australian|date=21 July 2011|accessdate=21 July 2011|title=US may quit troubled Bahrain|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/us-fleet-may-quit-troubled-bahrain/story-e6frg6so-1226098580227}} The United States and the United Kingdom have condemned the use of violence by Bahraini authorities. They did not call for regime change or threaten [[economic sanctions|sanctions]].{{cite news | author=[[Staff writer]] | date=19 February 2011 | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12514696 | title = Hague Condemns Violence in Libya, Bahrain and Yemen |publisher=BBC News | accessdate=21 April 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/politico44/perm/0411/long_distance_116efb9e-ca50-4ba7-be23-f14cd0105462.html|agency=Politico|date=30 April 2011|accessdate=1 May 2011|title=Obama dials Bahrain, Kazakhstan}} Iran has expressed strong support for demonstrators, the majority of whom follow [[Shia]] Islam, the Iranian state religion.[[Staff writer]] (16 March 2011). [http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/0316/breaking3.html "Iran Condemns Bahraini Assault"]. [[Reuters]] (via ''[[The Irish Times]]''). [http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2011/03/20/Iran-escalates-diplomatic-row-with-Bahrain/UPI-81421300644104/ "Iran Escalates Diplomatic Row with Bahrain"]. [[United Press International]]. Retrieved 19 April 2011.{{cite web | author=[[Staff writer]] | url = http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?storyid=301887 | title = Bahrain Recalls Envoy to Iran | work=[[Gulf Daily News]] | date=16 March 2011 | accessdate=19 April 2011}} Iran was joined by [[Iraq]] in opposing the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]]'s military intervention in Bahrain.{{cite web | author=[[Staff writer]] | date=17 March 2011 | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/03/17/3166047.htm?section=justin | title = Shiites Rally Behind Bahrain Protesters | publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] (via [[ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)|ABC News]]) | accessdate=20 April 2011}} Allies of the Bahraini government, such as [[Saudi Arabia]] and other GCC member states, have conversely blamed Iran for inciting upheaval in the small archipelago country and questioned the legitimacy of the protesters' demands,{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/bahrain-crackdown-fueling-tensions-between-iran-saudi-arabia/2011/04/21/AFVe6WPE_story.html|agency=The Washington Post|date=22 April 2011|accessdate=21 July 2011|title=Bahrain crackdown fueling tensions between Iran, Saudi Arabia|first=Greg|last=Jaffe}} echoing Manama's claims.{{cite news|url=http://ipsnews.net/news.asp?idnews=56562|agency=IPS News|date=20 July 2011|accessdate=21 July 2011|title=Bitter Divides Persist Below Bahrain's Relatively Calm Surface|last=Slavin|first=Barbara}} Thousands of [[2011 Iraqi protests|Shia protesters]] arose in [[Iraq]] and [[Qatif]], Saudi Arabia, in opposition to the [[Peninsula Shield Force|Saudi-led]] intervention in Bahrain.
